author: fradamt
content: They use polynomial commitments instead of merkle roots, but otherwise I agree that the validity proof can verify that the commitment matches the state diff it produces (or whatever the data is in relation to the computation). I was more wondering if there's annoying edge cases caused by the fact that the data and proof are not published together. It seems to me that at worst you'd get a proof which doesn't find the data, because it has ended up on a different branch or because the shard is slow, which is a bit annoying and wastes a bit of gas but not a huge deal.  This should also be pretty rare because a prover wouldn't start doing the proof until it has the whole batch (right?), and by the time it has the proof the shard data blob should be crosslinked and with a few confirmations. I am curious if that's really all there is to it?
